text: (upbeat music)
- My name is Kaartik.

I lead the engineering
team for AWS Config.
So if you look at Config as a service,
we provide customers the ability
to track changes to their resources,
as well as we provide customers an ability
to implement compliance.
It's a tier zero service for AWS,
and customers rely on Config
for business-critical decisions.

We have a pretty varied and
diverse engineering team,
backend developers, full stack developers,
as well as focused front-end developers.

It's a great mix, and even
if you look at the team,

the team is spread across
various locations within the US
giving the engineers a flexibility
to be remote, be closer to their family
to take care of any family issues.

So one of the things
that we've found is like

so we give engineers
the opportunity where,
hey, I worked on this particular project

for any number of months, now
I want to try something else.
So you have the opportunity
to try different aspects of the service.
It's like working in a startup
where you're moving fast towards a goal.

So I've been with AWS now
for almost eight years.

I started in AWS heading
a product management
for EC2 networking.

During part of our
regular yearly planning,
I proposed an idea for a new service,
and then my boss told me,
"Why don't you go build it yourself?"
So I switched from being a product manager

to a general manager where
I built a team from scratch,
built a service from scratch,

which was, it's like you're
the CEO of a company.
After I did that,

we launched the services
very successful today.
Then I switched to this current role
where I switched from a general manager
to heading up the engineering.

So one of the great things
I like with AWS and Amazon

is you have the opportunities
to push yourself

to grow professionally
if you are willing to say
that this is what I want to achieve.
The opportunities always present itself,

and so all I had to do is
go and tell my manager,

"Hey, I want to do this
at some point of time."

And that's something that they're
constantly keeping in mind

and when the right
opportunity presents itself,
then you're paired up to actually go build

what you want to do, so it's
been a great journey for me.
